Massive Digital Over-the-Air Computation for Communication-Efficient Federated Edge Learning

Li Qiao, , Zhen Gao, ,
Mahdi Boloursaz Mashhadi, , and Deniz Gündüz Part of the results were presented at the 2023 IEEE International Symposium on Information Theory (ISIT) [1].L. Abstract

Over-the-air computation (AirComp) is a promising technology converging communication and computation over wireless networks, which can be particularly effective in model training, inference, and more emerging edge intelligence applications. AirComp relies on uncoded transmission of individual signals, which are added naturally over the multiple access channel thanks to the superposition property of the wireless medium. Despite significantly improved communication efficiency, how to accommodate AirComp in the existing and future digital communication networks, that are based on discrete modulation schemes, remains a challenge. This paper proposes a massive digital AirComp (MD-AirComp) scheme, that leverages an unsourced massive access protocol, to enhance compatibility with both current and next-generation wireless networks. MD-AirComp utilizes vector quantization to reduce the uplink communication overhead, and employs shared quantization and modulation codebooks. At the receiver, we propose a near-optimal approximate message passing-based algorithm to compute the model aggregation results from the superposed sequences, which relies on estimating the number of devices transmitting each code sequence, rather than trying to decode the messages of individual transmitters. We apply MD-AirComp to the federated edge learning (FEEL), and show that it significantly accelerates FEEL convergence compared to state-of-the-art while using the same amount of communication resources. To support further research and ensure reproducibility, we have made our code available at https://github.com/liqiao19/MD-AirComp.

Index Terms:
Artificial intelligence of things (AIoT), digital over-the-air computation, unsourced random access, federated edge learning, distributed optimization.

I Introduction

With the advancement of the Artificial Intelligence of Things (AIoT), a growing volume of data is being generated by a massive number of Internet-of-Things (IoT) devices, which fuels the ongoing revolution in machine learning (ML) and artificial intelligence (AI) [2, 3]. Traditionally, data collected by IoT devices is offloaded to the cloud or data centers to train massively large models [4]. However, due to concerns over data privacy and the increasing computational capabilities of edge devices like smartphones, AIoT in wireless networks is transitioning away from centralized deep learning towards distributed learning frameworks [5, 4, 7, 6]. One of these emerging frameworks is federated edge learning (FEEL), where a central server coordinates multiple AIoT devices to train an ML model using their respective local datasets and computing resources [8]. As a result, FEEL requires solving the parallel and distributed optimization problem while considering the limited shared wireless resources and interference between devices. The model aggregation process in FEEL involves the repeated uplink (UL) transmission of high-dimensional local gradients or model updates from tens to hundreds of devices, which causes a heavy burden on the multiple access networks [9].

I-A Related Work

To address this problem, the concept of over-the-air computation (AirComp) has been introduced as a means of achieving communication-efficient model aggregation [8, 9, 10]. In the context of model aggregation, the objective is to compute the average of all the local model updates, rather than decoding each transmitted message individually. In analog AirComp, the fundamental principle involves generating and utilizing inter-user interference over the multiple-access channel (MAC). More specifically, every element of the local model update at a device goes through pre-equalization using the inverse of the UL channel gain from the device to the BS acting as the parameter server. Subsequently, the pre-equalized elements are modulated onto the transmit waveform’s amplitude. Through simultaneous transmission from multiple devices, the receiver can directly obtain the sum of the local model updates from multiple devices by leveraging the superposed waveform over the MAC. To further reduce the communication overhead, by exploiting sparsification and error accumulation, the dimension of the local model updates are reduced before analog transmission in [10]. After analog AirComp, the receiver reconstructs the average of local model updates by using the approximate message passing (AMP) algorithm. A higher FEEL accuracy is achieved with limited communication resources in [11], by exploiting time-correlated sparsification on the local model updates. Multi-input multi-output (MIMO)-based AirComp is studied in [12]. Random projection technique proposed in [10] is extended to MIMO channel in [13]. Note that all the participating devices are synchronized in time in [10, 8, 9, 11, 12, 13]. If the synchronization is imperfect, [14] and [15] considered misaligned analog AirComp to solve the problem. Dynamic scheduling of devices is proposed in [16] to optimize the energy efficiency of AirComp in FEEL. We refer the readers to [17] and [18] for a comprehensive overview of FEEL and AirComp. We should emphasize that AirComp is a general technology that turns wireless medium into a joint communication and computation platform. Its benefits can also be applied to other parallel and distributed optimization applications [19]. For instance, AirComp has recently been used for efficient inference at the edge [20, 21].

Despite the significant potential benefits of AirComp, most of the existing wireless networks adopt digital communication protocols (e.g., 3rd Generation Partnership Project standards) as well as hardware [22]. In other words, both existing and next-generation wireless networks may not have the flexibility to support any arbitrary modulation scheme, which is a fundamental requirement for the analog AirComp methods described earlier. As for digital communication, quantization, i.e., the process of mapping continuous values to a finite set of discrete values, is necessary. Quantization of model parameters in federated learning (FL) has been studied extensively, considering rate-limited error-free communication links from devices to the parameter server [23, 27, 24, 28, 25, 26]. Specifically, the authors of [23] analyzed the convergence of FL with stochastic uniform quantization. To optimize the convergence speed of FL with quantization, adaptive quantization levels were investigated in [24] and [25]. In addition, joint optimization of bandwidth and quantization levels was considered in [26]. To further reduce the UL communication overhead, vector quantization (VQ) have shown a significant improvement on the communication efficiency in [27] and [28]. Different from the orthogonal UL transmission considered in [23, 27, 24, 28, 25, 26], the authors of [29] proposed one-bit digital aggregation (OBDA) scheme for FEEL, which combines the ideas of AirComp and sign stochastic gradient descent (signSGD). Specifically, one-bit gradient quantization and digital modulation are adopted at devices, and majority-vote based gradient-decoding via AirComp is employed at the central server. Furthermore, non-coherent detector was proposed in [30] and [31], enabling scalar quantization-based digital AirComp without the need of channel state information (CSI). Despite its potential, this approach needs to allocate multiple frequencies to represent the quantization levels, thus raising concerns regarding spectral efficiency. In addition, a series of coding schemes recently proposed in [32, 33, 34] enables function computation from superposed digital constellations. However, these emerging digital AirComp schemes, i.e., [29, 30, 31, 32, 33, 34], only enables scalar quantization, and it is not clear how/if these approaches can be extended to VQ to further reduce the communication overhead. Hence, this necessities a novel communication-efficient digital AirComp scheme that is suitable for any scalar or vector quantization scheme and can be deployed in existing digital communication systems.

To fill in this gap, we propose a digital scheme that jointly enables random access and computation among massive AIoT devices. We first revisit grant-free random access (GFRA) protocols, which have been recently studied to enable massive IoT access with low signaling overhead and latency [35]. Since devices can directly transmit their signals without the permission of the base station (BS), GFRA protocols reduce the signaling overhead. There are mainly two types of GFRA schemes, i.e., sourced massive access (SMA) [36, 37, 38, 39, 40] and unsourced massive access (UMA) [42, 41, 44, 43]. Both SMA and UMA schemes adopt non-orthogonal random access codebook for reducing the communication overhead. In SMA, each device has its unique non-orthogonal preamble indicating its identity. The BS performs active device detection and channel estimation, followed by data decoding [37, 38, 39, 40]. In UMA, instead, all the devices adopt the same non-orthogonal codebook. Transmitted bits are modulated by the index of the UMA codewords and decoded at the BS. The goal of the BS is to decode the list of transmitted messages, but not the identities of the active devices [42, 44, 41, 43]. We remark that the identities of active devices are not necessary for model aggregation in FEEL either. Inspired by UMA, our target is to redesign the modulation and decoding modules of conventional UMA for efficient AirComp across a large number of devices.

I-B Contributions

To improve the communication efficiency of FEEL, we propose a massive digital AirComp (MD-AirComp) scheme that can be deployed in existing and next-generation digital communication systems. Specifically, consider a scenario with multiple devices, each with its own signal vector. The goal of the receiver is to recover the average of these vectors. In MD-AirComp, individual signal vectors are quantized using the common VQ codebook. Then, the active devices select their transmit sequences from the common modulation codebook based on their quantization indices. Note that there is a one-to-one mapping between the quantization and modulation codebooks. After pre-equalization, the non-orthogonal sequences from active devices are transmitted and overlap at the BS. Then, an AMP-based digital aggregation (AMP-DA) algorithm is proposed at the BS to estimate the number of devices employing each modulation codeword. We remark that in most FEEL and edge inference applications, active devices are likely to transmit the same message, especially when their datasets/models are statistically similar [13, 20]. Our main contributions are summarized as follows:

  • ∙∙\bullet

    Communication-efficient MD-AirComp method: By exploiting the superposition property of MAC and VQ, an MD-AirComp scheme is proposed for communication-efficient FEEL across digital communication systems. Since the receiver is interested in the sum of the signal vectors, the MD-AirComp scheme is user-collision friendly. In addition, it can be deployed with any scalar or vector quantization scheme to exploit the distribution of the signal vectors for better training accuracy. Since our proposed MD-AirComp scheme is a general lossy computing scheme over a MAC, it can also be applied to other edge computing tasks, such as collaborative inference [20].

  • ∙∙\bullet

    Proposed AMP-DA algorithm for signal aggregation: Due to the sporadic activity of AIoT devices and the potentially high-resolution VQ in FEEL, the signal to be detected is inherently sparse. Moreover, due to similarities in local dataset, some devices are likely to transmit the same message, and user-collisions will make the signal even more sparse. In addition, non-zero elements in the signal are integers representing the numbers of devices selecting a specified codeword. By modeling these properties in the prior distribution, the proposed AMP-DA algorithm realizes efficient model aggregation. Furthermore, the AMP-DA algorithm uses majority voting to estimate the number of active devices and exploits the multiple observations from multi-antenna BS, to further enhance the detection accuracy.

  • ∙∙\bullet

    Convergence analysis of MD-AirComp-based FEEL: We analyze the convergence rate of FEEL when the proposed MD-AirComp scheme is employed. Specifically, we analyze the influence of errors, originating from VQ and wireless communication, on the convergence rate. The wireless communication error relates to the detection accuracy of the AMP-DA algorithm. Our findings indicate that the MD-AirComp-based FEEL achieves a convergence rate of 𝒪​(1T)𝒪1𝑇\mathcal{O}(\frac{1}{\sqrt{T}}), where T𝑇T is the number of global training rounds.

II System Model

As shown in Fig. 1, we consider K𝐾K single-antenna edge devices served by an M𝑀M-antenna BS in a cellular system. Each device k𝑘k, k∈[K]𝑘delimited-[]𝐾k\in[K], has its own local dataset ℬksubscriptℬ𝑘\mathcal{B}_{k}, which consists of labeled data samples. For convenience, we assume uniform sizes for local datasets, that is, |ℬk|=Bsubscriptℬ𝑘𝐵|\mathcal{B}_{k}|=B, ∀kfor-all𝑘\forall k. In FEEL, K𝐾K devices are coordinated by the the BS to solve the following distributed optimization problem in parallel

min𝐰∈ℝW​f​(𝐰)=1K​∑k=1KFk​(𝐰),subscriptmin𝐰superscriptℝ𝑊𝑓𝐰1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰\displaystyle\text{min}_{{\bf w}\in\mathbb{R}^{W}}f(\mathbf{w})=\frac{1}{K}\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}F_{k}(\mathbf{w}), (1)

where 𝐰∈ℝW𝐰superscriptℝ𝑊{\bf w}\in\mathbb{R}^{W} is the parameter vector of a common neural network model and Fk​(𝐰)subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰F_{k}(\mathbf{w}) is the local loss function.

We follow the seminal federated averaging (FedAvg) [45] algorithm111Although we consider FedAvg in this paper, an extension of the results to other federated optimization algorithms [46, 47, 48] is straightforward.. Specifically, in the (t−1𝑡1t-1)-th global training round of FEEL, ∀t∈[T]for-all𝑡delimited-[]𝑇\forall t\in[T], the BS broadcasts the current global model 𝐰t−1superscript𝐰𝑡1{\bf w}^{t-1} to the devices. where tl∈[Tl]subscript𝑡𝑙delimited-[]subscript𝑇𝑙{t_{l}}\in[T_{l}], 𝐰k,0t=𝐰t−1superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘0𝑡superscript𝐰𝑡1{\bf w}_{k,0}^{t}={\bf w}^{t-1}, 𝐰kt=𝐰k,Tltsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘subscript𝑇𝑙𝑡{\bf w}_{k}^{t}={\bf w}_{k,T_{l}}^{t}, ∇∇\nabla and ηlsubscript𝜂𝑙\eta_{l} denote the gradient operator and the local learning rate, respectively, Fk​(𝐰k,tl−1t,𝜺)subscript𝐹𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘subscript𝑡𝑙1𝑡𝜺F_{k}({\bf w}_{k,{t_{l}}-1}^{t},{\bm{\varepsilon}}) denotes the local loss of model 𝐰k,tl−1tsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘subscript𝑡𝑙1𝑡{\bf w}_{k,{t_{l}}-1}^{t} on training sample 𝜺𝜺{\bm{\varepsilon}} with respect to its true label.

According to (2), the local model update can be obtained as Δkt=𝐰kt−𝐰t−1superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘𝑡superscript𝐰𝑡1\Delta_{k}^{t}={\bf w}_{k}^{t}-{\bf w}^{t-1}, ∀k,tfor-all𝑘𝑡\forall k,t. Ideally, the local model updates will be transmitted to the BS for global model update. In practice, to reduce the communication cost of ΔktsuperscriptsubscriptΔ𝑘𝑡\Delta_{k}^{t}, compression222Note that the typically used quantization and sparsification are two kinds of compression methods. and error accumulation are commonly adopted in FEEL [10]. In particular, we denote 𝐬¯kt=Δkt+𝐞ktsuperscriptsubscript¯𝐬𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐞𝑘𝑡\overline{\bf s}_{k}^{t}=\Delta_{k}^{t}+{\bf e}_{k}^{t}, ∀k,tfor-all𝑘𝑡\forall k,t, where the local model update ΔktsuperscriptsubscriptΔ𝑘𝑡\Delta_{k}^{t} is compensated with the accumulated error vector 𝐞ktsuperscriptsubscript𝐞𝑘𝑡{\bf e}_{k}^{t}. In addition, 𝐞ktsuperscriptsubscript𝐞𝑘𝑡{\bf e}_{k}^{t} is defined as 𝐞kt=𝐬¯kt−1−𝒞​(𝐬¯kt−1)superscriptsubscript𝐞𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript¯𝐬𝑘𝑡1𝒞superscriptsubscript¯𝐬𝑘𝑡1{\bf e}_{k}^{t}=\overline{\bf s}_{k}^{t-1}-\mathcal{C}(\overline{\bf s}_{k}^{t-1}), where 𝒞​(⋅)𝒞⋅\mathcal{C}(\cdot) denotes compression on its argument and the output is the element-wise compressed values. It can be seen that the accumulated error vector keeps track of the values that are not updated to the BS due to compression, helping to accelerate the training [49]. Hence, the compressed local model update 𝐬kt=𝒞​(𝐬¯kt)superscriptsubscript𝐬𝑘𝑡𝒞superscriptsubscript¯𝐬𝑘𝑡{\bf s}_{k}^{t}=\mathcal{C}(\overline{\bf s}_{k}^{t}) is transmitted to the BS rather than ΔktsuperscriptsubscriptΔ𝑘𝑡\Delta_{k}^{t}, ∀k,tfor-all𝑘𝑡\forall k,t, to reduce the communication cost while maintaining good training accuracy.

Furthermore, it is commonly adopted that only Kasubscript𝐾𝑎K_{a} (Ka≪Kmuch-less-thansubscript𝐾𝑎𝐾K_{a}\ll K) devices are simultaneously active in AIoT networks [10, 26, 18]. We assume the set of active devices 𝒮asubscript𝒮𝑎\mathcal{S}_{a}, where |𝒮a|=Kasubscript𝒮𝑎subscript𝐾𝑎|\mathcal{S}_{a}|=K_{a}, send their compressed local model updates 𝐬ktsuperscriptsubscript𝐬𝑘𝑡{\bf s}_{k}^{t}, k∈𝒮a𝑘subscript𝒮𝑎k\in\mathcal{S}_{a}, to the BS in each round. If 𝐬ktsuperscriptsubscript𝐬𝑘𝑡{\bf s}_{k}^{t} can be perfectly obtained at the BS, the global model update 𝐬t∈ℝWsuperscript𝐬𝑡superscriptℝ𝑊{\bf s}^{t}\in\mathbb{R}^{W} can be calculated as

𝐬t=1Ka​∑k∈𝒮a𝐬kt.superscript𝐬𝑡1subscript𝐾𝑎subscript𝑘subscript𝒮𝑎superscriptsubscript𝐬𝑘𝑡\displaystyle{\bf s}^{t}=\dfrac{1}{K_{a}}\sum\nolimits_{k\in\mathcal{S}_{a}}{\bf s}_{k}^{t}. (3)

Then, the global model can be updated as

𝐰t+1=𝐰t+η​𝐬t,superscript𝐰𝑡1superscript𝐰𝑡𝜂superscript𝐬𝑡\displaystyle{\bf w}^{t+1}={\bf w}^{t}+\eta{\bf s}^{t}, (4)

where η𝜂\eta is the global learning rate. Finally, the updated parameter vector 𝐰t+1∈ℝWsuperscript𝐰𝑡1superscriptℝ𝑊{\bf w}^{t+1}\in\mathbb{R}^{W} is sent back to the devices. Steps (2), (3), and (4) are iterated until a convergence condition is met.

It is clear from (3) that only the sum of the local model updates, rather than the individual values, is needed at the BS. The BS does not need to identify the active devices either. However, due to the large dimension of the parameter vector and the large number of devices that can potentially participate in the training, there is a communication bottleneck in FEEL. Thereby, we propose a communication-efficient MD-AirComp scheme as explained in Section III.

Remark 1.

One of the reasons that Ka≪Kmuch-less-thansubscript𝐾𝑎𝐾K_{a}\ll K in FEEL, e.g., in literature [10, 26, 18], is the heterogeneous computation speeds of different devices [48]. For a given time slot, only the devices that already finished their computation task will transmit. Devices’ availability can be another reason, that devices can participate or leave at particular frames, as considered in typical IoT scenarios [2].

III The Proposed MD-AirComp Scheme

As shown in Fig. 2, the proposed MD-AirComp scheme consists of several modules, i.e., a quantization module, a codebook-based modulation module, and a pre-equalization module at the transmitter, a detection module and a digital aggregation module at the receiver. In addition, we use dotted boxes to describe the local training module and the model update module that are specific to FEEL. In the following, we will describe each of these modules in detail. For simplicity, we omit the index t𝑡t unless otherwise specified. We reemphasize that MD-AirComp is a general approach for lossy computation over a MAC. In this paper, we motivate it through its application to FEEL.

III-A Transmitter Design

At the transmitter, each active device first quantizes 𝐬¯k∈ℝWsubscript¯𝐬𝑘superscriptℝ𝑊\overline{\bf s}_{k}\in\mathbb{R}^{W}, and then modulates the quantized value to a common modulation codebook. All active devices transmit their modulation codewords simultaneously. Next, we explain each component in detail.

III-A1 Quantization Design

We will employ a single quantization codebook to be used by all the devices, denoted by 𝐔∈ℝQ×N𝐔superscriptℝ𝑄𝑁{\bf U}\in\mathbb{R}^{Q\times N}, where N=2J𝑁superscript2𝐽N=2^{J} denotes J𝐽J-bit quantization with N𝑁N quantization codewords, Q≥1𝑄1Q\geq 1 (Q∈ℕ𝑄ℕQ\in\mathbb{N}) denotes the length of each quantization codeword, i.e., 𝐮n∈ℝQsubscript𝐮𝑛superscriptℝ𝑄{\bf u}_{n}\in\mathbb{R}^{Q}, ∀n∈[N]for-all𝑛delimited-[]𝑁\forall n\in[N]. Note that Q=1𝑄1Q=1 and Q>1𝑄1Q>1 indicate scalar quantization and VQ, respectively.

The vector 𝐬¯k∈ℝWsubscript¯𝐬𝑘superscriptℝ𝑊\overline{\bf s}_{k}\in\mathbb{R}^{W} at device k𝑘k is divided into D=W/Q𝐷𝑊𝑄D=W/Q blocks. For simplicity, here we assume that W𝑊W can be divided by Q𝑄Q. Each block is then quantized independently using codebook 𝐔𝐔{\bf U}. Let 𝐬¯k∈ℝWsubscript¯𝐬𝑘superscriptℝ𝑊\overline{\bf s}_{k}\in\mathbb{R}^{W} be quantized into 𝐛k∈[N]Dsubscript𝐛𝑘superscriptdelimited-[]𝑁𝐷{\bf b}_{k}\in[N]^{D}, where the d𝑑d-th element of 𝐛ksubscript𝐛𝑘{\bf b}_{k}, [𝐛k]dsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐛𝑘𝑑[{\bf b}_{k}]_{d}, denotes the quantization index of the corresponding block. In particular, [𝐛k]dsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐛𝑘𝑑[{\bf b}_{k}]_{d} is identified by finding the quantization codeword with the minimum Euclidean distance, which can be expressed as

[𝐛k]d=arg⁡mini∈[N]⁡‖[𝐔]:,i−[𝐬¯k](d−1)​Q+1:d​Q‖2.subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐛𝑘𝑑subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑁subscriptnormsubscriptdelimited-[]𝐔:𝑖subscriptdelimited-[]subscript¯𝐬𝑘:𝑑1𝑄1𝑑𝑄2\displaystyle\left[{\bf b}_{k}\right]_{d}=\arg\min_{i\in[N]}\left\|\left[{\bf U}\right]_{:,i}-\left[\overline{\bf s}_{k}\right]_{(d-1)Q+1:dQ}\right\|_{2}. (5)

To determine the quantization codebook, we can use any VQ method. From (5), it can be seen that the size of each local model update can be reduced by using VQ, thereby decreasing the communication overhead in the UL by a factor of Q𝑄Q.

Furthermore, we introduce a one-hot vector 𝐱kd∈{0,1}Nsuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑘𝑑superscript01𝑁{\bf x}_{k}^{d}\in\{0,1\}^{N}, namely the selection vector, where ‖𝐱kd‖0=1subscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑘𝑑01\|{\bf x}_{k}^{d}\|_{0}=1 and [𝐱kd][𝐛k]d=1subscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑘𝑑subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐛𝑘𝑑1\left[{\bf x}_{k}^{d}\right]_{\left[{\bf b}_{k}\right]_{d}}=1. Hence, we can denote the quantized version of 𝐬¯ksubscript¯𝐬𝑘\overline{\bf s}_{k} as

𝐬k=𝒞​(𝐬¯k)=(𝐈D⊗𝐔)​[(𝐱k1)T,…,(𝐱kD)T]T,subscript𝐬𝑘𝒞subscript¯𝐬𝑘tensor-productsubscript𝐈𝐷𝐔superscriptsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑘1𝑇…superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑘𝐷𝑇𝑇\displaystyle{\bf s}_{k}=\mathcal{C}(\overline{\bf s}_{k})=\left({\bf I}_{D}\otimes{\bf U}\right)\left[({\bf x}_{k}^{1})^{T},...,({\bf x}_{k}^{D})^{T}\right]^{T}, (6)

where ⊗tensor-product\otimes and 𝐈Dsubscript𝐈𝐷{\bf I}_{D} denote the Kronecker product and the identity matrix of size D𝐷D, respectively.

III-A2 Codebook-Based Modulation

We consider the same random access codebook shared by all the devices, denoted by 𝐏∈ℂL×N𝐏superscriptℂ𝐿𝑁{\bf P}\in\mathbb{C}^{L\times N}, where each column of 𝐏𝐏{\bf P} is a codeword of length L𝐿L, and there are N𝑁N codewords in total. In the proposed scheme, there is a one-to-one mapping between 𝐏𝐏{\bf P} and 𝐔𝐔{\bf U}. To be specific, if the device acquires the quantized value [𝐔]:,nsubscriptdelimited-[]𝐔:𝑛[{\bf U}]_{:,n}, then the modulation codeword (or sequence) [𝐏]:,nsubscriptdelimited-[]𝐏:𝑛[{\bf P}]_{:,n} that has the same index n𝑛n will be transmitted. The transmission process is similar to the preamble transmission of random access procedure in 5G communication systems [22]. Hence, the proposed codebook-based modulation is more suitable for the current wireless networks compared to the analog modulation used in AirComp.

III-A3 UL Massive Access Model

We consider a time division duplex system, where the UL and downlink (DL) channels are commonly considered the same due to channel reciprocity [38, 43]. Before each UL communication round of FEEL, the BS first broadcasts a pilot signal and each active device estimates its DL channel based on the pilot signal. Then, the active devices start their grant-free UL transmissions with pre-equalization in a synchronized manner [38]. For the d𝑑d-th element of 𝐛ksubscript𝐛𝑘{\bf b}_{k}, ∀k,dfor-all𝑘𝑑\forall k,d, the received signal 𝐘d∈ℂL×Msubscript𝐘𝑑superscriptℂ𝐿𝑀{\bf Y}_{d}\in\mathbb{C}^{L\times M} at the BS can be expressed as

𝐘d=∑k∈𝒮a1[𝐡k]1​𝐏𝐱kd​(𝐡k)T+𝐙d=𝐏𝐗d+𝐙d,subscript𝐘𝑑subscript𝑘subscript𝒮𝑎1subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐡𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝐏𝐱𝑘𝑑superscriptsubscript𝐡𝑘𝑇subscript𝐙𝑑subscript𝐏𝐗𝑑subscript𝐙𝑑\displaystyle{\bf Y}_{d}=\sum\limits_{k\in\mathcal{S}_{a}}\dfrac{1}{[{\bf h}_{k}]_{1}}{\bf P}{\bf x}_{k}^{d}\left({\bf h}_{k}\right)^{T}+{\bf Z}_{d}={\bf P}{\bf X}_{d}+{\bf Z}_{d}, (7)

where the elements of the UL channel vector 𝐡k∈ℂMsubscript𝐡𝑘superscriptℂ𝑀{\bf h}_{k}\in\mathbb{C}^{M} are assumed to follow a complex Gaussian distribution with zero mean and unit variance, while channel inversion is considered for the first antenna of the BS333Since each device has a single antenna, it is only possible to apply channel inversion for one of the antennas at the BS. For simplicity, we consider channel inversion for the first antenna of the BS. Also, we assume the channel reciprocity and perfect DL channel estimation at the devices [38]. Imperfect channel estimation will be discussed in Section VI-E.. 𝐗d=∑k∈𝒮a1[𝐡k]1​𝐱kd​(𝐡k)T∈ℂN×Msubscript𝐗𝑑subscript𝑘subscript𝒮𝑎1subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐡𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑘𝑑superscriptsubscript𝐡𝑘𝑇superscriptℂ𝑁𝑀{\bf X}_{d}=\sum\nolimits_{k\in\mathcal{S}_{a}}\frac{1}{[{\bf h}_{k}]_{1}}{\bf x}_{k}^{d}({\bf h}_{k})^{T}\in\mathbb{C}^{N\times M} is the equivalent transmit signal, and elements of the noise vector 𝐙d∈ℂL×Msubscript𝐙𝑑superscriptℂ𝐿𝑀{\bf Z}_{d}\in\mathbb{C}^{L\times M} obeys the independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.) complex Gaussian distribution with zero mean and variance σn2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑛2\sigma_{n}^{2}. We define the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) SNR≜10​log10​‖𝐏𝐗d‖F2L​M​σn2≜SNR10subscriptlog10superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝐏𝐗𝑑𝐹2𝐿𝑀superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑛2\text{SNR}\triangleq 10\text{log}_{10}\frac{\|{\bf P}{\bf X}_{d}\|_{F}^{2}}{LM\sigma_{n}^{2}}. Hence, the first column of 𝐗dsubscript𝐗𝑑{\bf X}_{d} obeys the following properties,

‖[𝐗d]:,1‖1=Ka,‖[𝐗d]:,1‖0≤Ka,[𝐗d]n,1∈Ω,∀n,formulae-sequencesubscriptnormsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐗𝑑:11subscript𝐾𝑎formulae-sequencesubscriptnormsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐗𝑑:10subscript𝐾𝑎subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐗𝑑𝑛1Ωfor-all𝑛\displaystyle\left\|\left[{\bf X}_{d}\right]_{:,1}\right\|_{1}=K_{a},~{}\left\|\left[{\bf X}_{d}\right]_{:,1}\right\|_{0}\leq K_{a},~{}\left[{\bf X}_{d}\right]_{n,1}\in\Omega,\forall n, (8)

where Ω={0,[Ka]}Ω0delimited-[]subscript𝐾𝑎\Omega=\{0,[K_{a}]\}. It can be seen that the n𝑛n-th column of 𝐏𝐏{\bf P} is transmitted by [𝐗d]n,1subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐗𝑑𝑛1[{\bf X}_{d}]_{n,1} active devices, or equivalently the n𝑛n-th quantization codeword appears at [𝐗d]n,1subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐗𝑑𝑛1[{\bf X}_{d}]_{n,1} devices, which indicates how to conduct the model aggregation. The non-zero elements of [𝐗d]:,msubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐗𝑑:𝑚[{\bf X}_{d}]_{:,m}, m∈{2,3,…,M}𝑚23…𝑀m\in\{2,3,...,M\}, obey the ratio distribution of two uncorrelated complex Gaussian variables as discussed in [50]. Furthermore, due to the multiple observations at multiple antennas at the BS, 𝐗dsubscript𝐗𝑑{\bf X}_{d} has row sparsity [36], which can be expressed as

supp​{[𝐗d]:,1}=supp​{[𝐗d]:,2}=⋯=supp​{[𝐗d]:,M},suppsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐗𝑑:1suppsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐗𝑑:2⋯suppsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐗𝑑:𝑀\displaystyle\text{supp}\left\{\left[{\bf X}_{d}\right]_{:,1}\right\}=\text{supp}\left\{\left[{\bf X}_{d}\right]_{:,2}\right\}=\cdots=\text{supp}\left\{\left[{\bf X}_{d}\right]_{:,M}\right\}, (9)

where supp​{⋅}supp⋅\text{supp}\left\{\cdot\right\} denotes the index of non-zero elements (rows) of a vector (matrix). Both (8) and (9) will be exploited to reconstruct [𝐗d]:,1subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐗𝑑:1\left[{\bf X}_{d}\right]_{:,1}, ∀dfor-all𝑑\forall d, in Section IV.

Remark 2.

As shown in (7), the noise power can be defined by the SNR and the average power of the received signal, which is commonly used in massive access system models [35]. If the wireless channel [𝐡kUL]1subscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐡𝑘UL1[{\bf h}_{k}^{\rm UL}]_{1} is in deep fading, the power of [𝐡kUL]1subscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐡𝑘UL1[{\bf h}_{k}^{\rm UL}]_{1} can be extremely small. In this case, pre-equalization might increase the received signal power at the rest of the antennas. As a result, SNR at the first antenna can be too small to conduct proper signal detection. In addition, if the channel power is too small, the transmit power needed for pre-equalization might be too large. Hence, we set a threshold ϵhsubscriptitalic-ϵℎ\epsilon_{h} on the channel condition, such that if |[𝐡k]1|<ϵhsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐡𝑘1subscriptitalic-ϵℎ|[{\bf h}_{k}]_{1}|<\epsilon_{h}, the device will not participate in this training round.

III-B Receiver Design

According to (3), the receiver’s target in MD-AirComp is to compute the aggregated global model update 𝐬∈ℝW𝐬superscriptℝ𝑊{\bf s}\in\mathbb{R}^{W}, which can be expressed as

𝐬𝐬\displaystyle{\bf s} =1Ka​(𝐈D⊗𝐔)​[(∑k∈𝒮a𝐱k1)T,…,(∑k∈𝒮a𝐱kD)T]Tabsent1subscript𝐾𝑎tensor-productsubscript𝐈𝐷𝐔superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑘subscript𝒮𝑎superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑘1𝑇…superscriptsubscript𝑘subscript𝒮𝑎superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑘𝐷𝑇𝑇\displaystyle=\dfrac{1}{{K}_{a}}\left({\bf I}_{D}\otimes{\bf U}\right)\left[\left(\sum\limits_{k\in\mathcal{S}_{a}}{\bf x}_{k}^{1}\right)^{T},...,\left(\sum\limits_{k\in\mathcal{S}_{a}}{\bf x}_{k}^{D}\right)^{T}\right]^{T}
=1Ka​(𝐈D⊗𝐔)​[([𝐗1]:,1)T,…,([𝐗D]:,1)T]T.absent1subscript𝐾𝑎tensor-productsubscript𝐈𝐷𝐔superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐗1:1𝑇…superscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐗𝐷:1𝑇𝑇\displaystyle=\dfrac{1}{{K}_{a}}\left({\bf I}_{D}\otimes{\bf U}\right)\left[\left(\left[{\bf X}_{1}\right]_{:,1}\right)^{T},...,\left(\left[{\bf X}_{D}\right]_{:,1}\right)^{T}\right]^{T}. (10)

It can be seen that the main differences between (III-B) and the decoding problem of UMA are as follows

  • •

    The proposed MD-AirComp scheme is collision friendly: In particular, the superposed equivalent signal vector [𝐗d]:,1subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐗𝑑:1[{\bf X}_{d}]_{:,1} is used for the computing task (III-B) as a whole. Hence, it is unnecessary to decode each device’s data from [𝐗d]:,1subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐗𝑑:1[{\bf X}_{d}]_{:,1}, ∀dfor-all𝑑\forall d. As a result, it is unnecessary to avoid collisions of multiple devices.

  • •

    Detection algorithms for UMA do not apply to MD-AirComp: In UMA, since data is embedded in the index of the transmitted codeword, detection algorithms focus on estimating the support of 𝐗dsubscript𝐗𝑑{\bf X}_{d} rather than its values, ∀dfor-all𝑑\forall d. Furthermore, the number of active users Kasubscript𝐾𝑎K_{a} is trivial in UMA, but its detection is crucial for (III-B). In addition, due to pre-equalization in MD-AirComp, the received signal distributions on the first antenna and the remaining antennas are different.

III-B1 CS-Based Detection

To achieve higher quantization accuracy, especially for VQ, the number of quantization bits J𝐽J can be set very large, e.g., more than 8 bits. In this case, N=2J𝑁superscript2𝐽N=2^{J} can be far greater than Kasubscript𝐾𝑎K_{a} (i.e., Ka≪Nmuch-less-thansubscript𝐾𝑎𝑁K_{a}\ll N), which motivates us to employ non-orthogonal codebook 𝐏𝐏{\bf P} (L<N𝐿𝑁L<N) and CS-based detection algorithms to reduce the communication overhead. Thanks to the sparsity of the equivalent signal [𝐗d]:,1subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐗𝑑:1[{\bf X}_{d}]_{:,1}, i.e., the number of non-zero elements ‖[𝐗d]:,1‖0≤Ka≪Nsubscriptnormsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐗𝑑:10subscript𝐾𝑎much-less-than𝑁\|[{\bf X}_{d}]_{:,1}\|_{0}\leq K_{a}\ll N, we can employ CS-based algorithms to estimate 𝐱dsubscript𝐱𝑑{\bf x}_{d}. Note that the codebook 𝐏𝐏{\bf P} is known at the BS. Our design target is to estimate the elements [𝐗d]:,1subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐗𝑑:1[{\bf X}_{d}]_{:,1} as accurate as possible. The details of the proposed CS-based detection algorithm will be given in Section IV.

Furthermore, since the number of non-zero elements ‖[𝐗d]:,1‖0subscriptnormsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐗𝑑:10\|[{\bf X}_{d}]_{:,1}\|_{0} will decrease if more users transmit the same codeword, the interference improves sparsity thereby becomes helpful for the CS-based detection. Hence, unlike the traditional UMA [42], user collision avoidance is unnecessary.

III-B2 Digital Aggregation

After CS-based detection, we can obtain an estimate of the equivalent transmit signals, denoted by [𝐗^d]:,1subscriptdelimited-[]subscript^𝐗𝑑:1[\widehat{\bf X}_{d}]_{:,1}, ∀dfor-all𝑑\forall d. According to (8), estimated number of active devices K^asubscript^𝐾𝑎\widehat{K}_{a} can be obtained by calculating ‖[𝐗^d]:,1‖1subscriptnormsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript^𝐗𝑑:11\|[\widehat{\bf X}_{d}]_{:,1}\|_{1}, ∀dfor-all𝑑\forall d, which will be illustrated in Section IV-C in detail. Then, by substituting K^asubscript^𝐾𝑎\widehat{K}_{a} and [𝐗^d]:,1subscriptdelimited-[]subscript^𝐗𝑑:1[\widehat{\bf X}_{d}]_{:,1} into (III-B), we obtain the estimated global model update 𝐬^^𝐬\widehat{\bf s}.

III-B3 Model Update

According to (4) and (III-B), BS updates the weight of the ML model as

𝐰^t+1=𝐰^t+η⋅𝐬^t,superscript^𝐰𝑡1superscript^𝐰𝑡⋅𝜂superscript^𝐬𝑡\displaystyle\widehat{\bf w}^{t+1}=\widehat{\bf w}^{t}+\eta\cdot\widehat{\bf s}^{t}, (11)

and broadcasts it to all the devices and the next training round starts. Finally, the proposed MD-AirComp based FEEL procedure is summarized in Algorithm 1.

IV Proposed CS-Based Digital Aggregation Algorithm

In this section, we will first introduce the CS-based problem formulation. Furthermore, we propose the AMP-based algorithm for efficient detection and Kasubscript𝐾𝑎K_{a} estimation. Finally, we summarize the proposed AMP-DA algorithm and analyse its computational complexity. For simplicity, we omit the subscript d𝑑d in this section unless otherwise specified.

IV-A Problem Formulation

According to (III-B), since 𝐔𝐔{\bf U} and 𝐏𝐏{\bf P} are known at the receiver, the target of the BS is to estimate [𝐗]:,1subscriptdelimited-[]𝐗:1[{\bf X}]_{:,1} and Kasubscript𝐾𝑎K_{a} from the observation 𝐘𝐘{\bf Y}, as shown in (7). Hence, the detection problem at the BS can be formulated as follows

min𝐗,Ka‖𝐘−𝐏𝐗‖F2subscript𝐗subscript𝐾𝑎superscriptsubscriptnorm𝐘𝐏𝐗𝐹2\displaystyle\min_{{\bf X},K_{a}}\quad\left\|{\bf Y}-{\bf PX}\right\|_{F}^{2} (12)
s.t.(8),(9),andKa≪N.\displaystyle\begin{array}[]{r@{\quad}r@{}l@{\quad}l}s.t.\quad(\ref{SpaX}),\quad(\ref{SparseMIMO}),\quad\text{and}\quad K_{a}\ll N.\end{array}

The optimization problem (LABEL:P) minimizes the mean square error (MSE) between 𝐘𝐘{\bf Y} and 𝐏𝐗𝐏𝐗{\bf PX}, which is equivalent to calculate the posterior mean of 𝐗𝐗{\bf X} under the Bayesian framework [51]. In the following, we denote [𝐗]n,msubscriptdelimited-[]𝐗𝑛𝑚[{\bf X}]_{n,m} as xn,msubscript𝑥𝑛𝑚x_{n,m}, where n∈[N]𝑛delimited-[]𝑁n\in[N] and m∈[M]𝑚delimited-[]𝑀m\in[M]. Furthermore, the posterior mean of xn,msubscript𝑥𝑛𝑚x_{n,m}, ∀n,mfor-all𝑛𝑚\forall n,m, can be expressed as

x^n,m=∫xn,m​p​(xn,m|[𝐘]:,m)​𝑑xn,m,subscript^𝑥𝑛𝑚subscript𝑥𝑛𝑚𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑥𝑛𝑚subscriptdelimited-[]𝐘:𝑚differential-dsubscript𝑥𝑛𝑚\displaystyle\widehat{x}_{n,m}={\int}x_{n,m}p\left(x_{n,m}|[{\bf Y}]_{:,m}\right)dx_{n,m}, (13)

where p​(xn,m|[𝐘]:,m)𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑥𝑛𝑚subscriptdelimited-[]𝐘:𝑚p(x_{n,m}|[{\bf Y}]_{:,m}) is the marginal distribution of p​([𝐗]:,m|[𝐘]:,m)𝑝conditionalsubscriptdelimited-[]𝐗:𝑚subscriptdelimited-[]𝐘:𝑚p([{\bf X}]_{:,m}|[{\bf Y}]_{:,m}) and it can be written as

p​(xn,m|[𝐘]:,m)=∫\xn,mp​([𝐗]:,m|[𝐘]:,m).𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑥𝑛𝑚subscriptdelimited-[]𝐘:𝑚subscript\absentsubscript𝑥𝑛𝑚𝑝conditionalsubscriptdelimited-[]𝐗:𝑚subscriptdelimited-[]𝐘:𝑚\displaystyle\vspace{-3mm}p\left(x_{n,m}|[{\bf Y}]_{:,m}\right)={\int}_{\backslash x_{n,m}}p\left([{\bf X}]_{:,m}|[{\bf Y}]_{:,m}\right).\vspace{-3mm} (14)

As discussed in Section III-B, to achieve higher quantization accuracy, more quantization bits are needed for higher dimensional VQ. This can result in a large dimension of N𝑁N, which demands a computationally efficient algorithm to calculate the marginal distribution p​(xn|𝐲)𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑥𝑛𝐲p(x_{n}|{\bf{y}}). To address this issue, the AMP algorithm can be adopted to obtain the approximate marginal distributions with relatively low complexity, while achieving near minimum mean square error (MMSE) performance [52].

IV-B Approximate Message Passing (AMP) Update Rules

According to the AMP algorithm [52], in the large system regime, the estimation problem (7) can be approximately decoupled into N𝑁N scalar problems as

𝐘=𝐏𝐗+𝐙→rn,m=xn,m+zn,m,∀n,m,formulae-sequence𝐘𝐏𝐗𝐙→subscript𝑟𝑛𝑚subscript𝑥𝑛𝑚subscript𝑧𝑛𝑚for-all𝑛𝑚\begin{array}[]{l}{\bf Y}={\bf P}{\bf{X}}+{\bf{Z}}\;\to\;r_{n,m}=x_{n,m}+z_{n,m},~{}\forall n,m,\end{array} (15)

IV-C Parameter Estimation

IV-C1 Estimation of Kasubscript𝐾𝑎K_{a}

According to (25), we can obtain the estimated equivalent transmit signal vector [𝐗^d]:,1subscriptdelimited-[]subscript^𝐗𝑑:1[\widehat{\bf X}_{d}]_{:,1}, where the superscript d𝑑d denotes the d𝑑d-th block, ∀d∈[D]for-all𝑑delimited-[]𝐷\forall d\in[D]. In addition, as indicated in (8), ‖[𝐗^d]:,1‖1subscriptnormsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript^𝐗𝑑:11\|[\widehat{\bf X}_{d}]_{:,1}\|_{1} should equal to Kasubscript𝐾𝑎K_{a}, in the case of perfect detection. To improve the robustness, we propose to acquire K^asubscript^𝐾𝑎\widehat{K}_{a} as follows

K^a=Ψ​{⌊‖[𝐗^d]:,1‖1+12⌋,d∈[D]},subscript^𝐾𝑎Ψsubscriptnormsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript^𝐗𝑑:1112𝑑delimited-[]𝐷\displaystyle\widehat{K}_{a}\!=\!\Psi\left\{\left\lfloor\left\|[\widehat{\bf X}_{d}]_{:,1}\right\|_{1}\!\!+\!\frac{1}{2}\right\rfloor,d\in[D]\right\}, (34)

where function Ψ​{⋅}Ψ⋅\Psi\left\{\cdot\right\} calculates the most frequently occurring element of its argument. The intuition of (34) is from majority voting [29], which improves the detection accuracy of Kasubscript𝐾𝑎K_{a}. We note that once K^asubscript^𝐾𝑎\widehat{K}_{a} is estimated, it is possible to go back and update the estimates of those blocks for which the estimated 𝐗^dsubscript^𝐗𝑑\widehat{\bf X}_{d} did not correspond to K^asubscript^𝐾𝑎\widehat{K}_{a} active devices. We do not carry out this refinement in this paper.

IV-C2 Estimation of the activity indicators

The unknown parameter, denoted by 𝜽={an,m,σ2,τ0,μ0,n∈[N],m∈[M]}\bm{\theta}=\{a_{n,m},\sigma^{2},\tau_{0},\mu_{0},n\in[N],m\in[M]\}, can be obtained by using the expectation maximization (EM) algorithm [55]. The EM algorithm is an iterative approach that effectively finds the maximum likelihood solutions for probabilistic models with unknown parameters [55]. Here, the EM update rules are as follows

𝜽i+1=arg​max𝜽⁡𝔼​{ln​p​(𝐗,𝐘)|𝐘;𝜽i},superscript𝜽𝑖1argsubscript𝜽𝔼conditional-setln𝑝𝐗𝐘𝐘superscript𝜽𝑖\displaystyle\bm{\theta}^{i+1}={\rm arg}\max\limits_{\bm{\theta}}\mathbb{E}\left\{{{\rm ln}~{}p\left({{\bf X,Y}}\right)|{\bf Y};\bm{\theta}^{i}}\right\}, (35)

where 𝜽isuperscript𝜽𝑖\bm{\theta}^{i} denotes the unknown parameter in the i𝑖i-th iteration, 𝔼{⋅|𝐘;𝜽i}\mathbb{E}\{\cdot|{\bf Y};\bm{\theta}^{i}\} represents the expectation conditioned on the received signal 𝐘𝐘{\bf Y} under 𝜽isuperscript𝜽𝑖\bm{\theta}^{i}.

For example, to estimate the activity indicator an,msubscript𝑎𝑛𝑚a_{n,m}, ∀n,mfor-all𝑛𝑚\forall n,m, we partially differentiate 𝔼​{ln​p​(𝐗,𝐘)|𝐘}𝔼conditional-setln𝑝𝐗𝐘𝐘\mathbb{E}\left\{{{\rm ln}~{}p\left({{\bf X,Y}}\right)|{\bf Y}}\right\} with respect to an,msubscript𝑎𝑛𝑚a_{n,m} and let it equal zero [55]. According to (IV-B), the posterior distribution p​(xn,m|[𝐘]:,m)𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑥𝑛𝑚subscriptdelimited-[]𝐘:𝑚p\left(x_{n,m}|[{\bf Y}]_{:,m}\right) can be approximated as p​(xn,m|rn,m)𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑥𝑛𝑚subscript𝑟𝑛𝑚p\left(x_{n,m}|r_{n,m}\right), thereby simplifying the complexity of EM estimation. Hence, according to (23) and (24), the sparsity indicators an,1subscript𝑎𝑛1a_{n,1} and an,msubscript𝑎𝑛𝑚a_{n,m}, m∈{2,3,…,M}𝑚23…𝑀m\in\{2,3,...,M\}, can be obtained as

(an,1)i+1superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑛1𝑖1\displaystyle(a_{n,1})^{i+1} =∑xn,1∈[Ka]p​(xn,1|rn,1;(an)i),absentsubscriptsubscript𝑥𝑛1delimited-[]subscript𝐾𝑎𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑥𝑛1subscript𝑟𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑛𝑖\displaystyle=\sum\nolimits_{x_{n,1}\in[K_{a}]}p\left(x_{n,1}|r_{n,1};(a_{n})^{i}\right), (36)
(an,m)i+1superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑛𝑚𝑖1\displaystyle(a_{n,m})^{i+1} =πn,m,absentsubscript𝜋𝑛𝑚\displaystyle=\pi_{n,m}, (37)

respectively. To exploit the row sparsity as indicated in (9), we further average the activity indicators on M𝑀M antennas as

(an)i+1=1M​∑m=1M(an,m)i+1,∀n.superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑛𝑖11𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑛𝑚𝑖1for-all𝑛\displaystyle(a_{n})^{i+1}=\frac{1}{M}\sum\nolimits_{m=1}^{M}(a_{n,m})^{i+1},\forall n. (38)

IV-C3 Estimation of other parameters

Furthermore, we apply the EM update rules (35) to estimate other unknown parameters. In particular, to estimate the noise variance, we partially differentiate 𝔼​{ln​p​(𝐗,𝐘)|𝐘}𝔼conditional-setln𝑝𝐗𝐘𝐘\mathbb{E}\left\{{{\rm ln}~{}p\left({{\bf X,Y}}\right)|{\bf Y}}\right\} with respect to σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} and let it equal zero [55]. Similarly, calculations can be done to obtain τ0subscript𝜏0\tau_{0} and μ0subscript𝜇0\mu_{0}. Note that only (24) includes τ0subscript𝜏0\tau_{0} and μ0subscript𝜇0\mu_{0}, suggesting that the messages from the first antenna do not contribute to the estimation of τ0subscript𝜏0\tau_{0} and μ0subscript𝜇0\mu_{0}. IV-D Proposed AMP-DA Algorithm

Based on (19)-(38), we summarize the proposed AMP-DA algorithm in Algorithm 2. The details are explained as follows. In line 1, we initialize the sparsity indicators andsubscriptsuperscript𝑎𝑑𝑛a^{d}_{n}, the variables Vl,mdsubscriptsuperscript𝑉𝑑𝑙𝑚V^{d}_{l,m}, Zl,mdsubscriptsuperscript𝑍𝑑𝑙𝑚Z^{d}_{l,m}, the posterior mean x^n,mdsuperscriptsubscript^𝑥𝑛𝑚𝑑{\widehat{x}}_{n,m}^{d}, and posterior variance v^n,mdsuperscriptsubscript^𝑣𝑛𝑚𝑑{\widehat{v}}_{n,m}^{d}, ∀d,n,l,mfor-all𝑑𝑛𝑙𝑚\forall d,n,l,m. The iteration starts in line 2. Specifically, lines 3-6 correspond to the AMP operation. In the i𝑖i-th iteration of the AMP decoupling step (line 3), Vl,mdsubscriptsuperscript𝑉𝑑𝑙𝑚V^{d}_{l,m}, Zl,mdsubscriptsuperscript𝑍𝑑𝑙𝑚Z^{d}_{l,m}, φn,mdsuperscriptsubscript𝜑𝑛𝑚𝑑\varphi_{n,m}^{d}, and rn,mdsuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑛𝑚𝑑r_{n,m}^{d}, are calculated according to (21), (22), (19), and (20), respectively. Furthermore, a damping parameter τ𝜏\tau is adopted in line 4 to prevent the algorithm from diverging [56]. In addition, in the AMP denoising steps (line 5 and line 6), we calculate the posterior mean x^n,1dsuperscriptsubscript^𝑥𝑛1𝑑{\widehat{x}}_{n,1}^{d} and the corresponding posterior variance v^n,1dsuperscriptsubscript^𝑣𝑛1𝑑{\widehat{v}}_{n,1}^{d}, of the i𝑖i-th iteration, by using (25) and (26), respectively. In addition, for m∈{2,…,M}𝑚2…𝑀m\in\{2,...,M\}, x^n,mdsuperscriptsubscript^𝑥𝑛𝑚𝑑{\widehat{x}}_{n,m}^{d} and v^n,mdsuperscriptsubscript^𝑣𝑛𝑚𝑑{\widehat{v}}_{n,m}^{d} are calculated by using (32) and (33). Accordingly, EM operation is used to update the sparsity indicators andsubscriptsuperscript𝑎𝑑𝑛a^{d}_{n}, the noise variance σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2}, and the mean and variance of the prior distribution μ0dsuperscriptsubscript𝜇0𝑑\mu_{0}^{d} and τ0dsuperscriptsubscript𝜏0𝑑\tau_{0}^{d}, respectively, in line 7. The residual of the i𝑖i-th iteration is calculated in line 8. Then, the iteration restarts in line 3 until the maximum iteration number I0subscript𝐼0I_{0} is reached. Otherwise, if line 10 is triggered, i.e., the residual does not goes down after at least 15 steps, we stop iterations. After the iteration, we acquire the estimated equivalent transmit signal 𝐱^d=[(𝐗^d)i]:,1subscript^𝐱𝑑subscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript^𝐗𝑑𝑖:1\widehat{\bf x}_{d}=[(\widehat{\bf X}_{d})^{i}]_{:,1}, ∀dfor-all𝑑{\forall d}, in line 14. According to (34), in line 15, we estimate the number of active devices K^asubscript^𝐾𝑎\widehat{K}_{a} based on 𝐱^dsubscript^𝐱𝑑\widehat{\bf x}_{d}, ∀dfor-all𝑑{\forall d}. Finally, according to (III-B) and Section III-B, we obtain the global model update 𝐬^^𝐬\widehat{\bf s} in line 16 by using 𝐱^dsubscript^𝐱𝑑\widehat{\bf x}_{d} and K^asubscript^𝐾𝑎\widehat{K}_{a}, ∀dfor-all𝑑{\forall d}, and the weight of the ML model will be updated using 𝐬^^𝐬\widehat{\bf s}.

Remark 3.

Since only [𝐗^d]:,1subscriptdelimited-[]subscript^𝐗𝑑:1[\widehat{\bf X}_{d}]_{:,1} matters for the computing task (III-B), the digital model aggregation can be done by only using the received signal at the first antenna of the BS, i.e., running Algorithm 2 except line 6. If multiple antennas are available at the BS, the proposed AMP-DA algorithm improves the estimation accuracy of [𝐗d]:,1subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐗𝑑:1[{\bf X}_{d}]_{:,1} by exploiting the row sparsity, as described in (9). As a result, the training accuracy of the proposed MD-AirComp improves with multi-antenna BS, which will be verified in the simulations.

IV-E Computational Complexity

The computational complexity of the proposed AMP-DA algorithm mainly comes from the complex-valued matrix multiplications, i.e., (19)-(22), (25), (26), (32), and (33), at each iteration. The overall computational complexity at one FEEL training round is of the order of 𝒪​(I0​L​N​M​D)𝒪subscript𝐼0𝐿𝑁𝑀𝐷{\cal O}(I_{0}LNMD), which equals to 𝒪​(I0​L​M​2J​W/Q)𝒪subscript𝐼0𝐿𝑀superscript2𝐽𝑊𝑄{\cal O}(I_{0}LM2^{J}W/Q). It can be seen that the overall complexity scales linearly with the quantization level N𝑁N, which is appealing for efficient detection with high-dimensional VQ along with a large quantization level. The computational complexity of our proposed AMP-DA algorithm can be reduced further by employing deep unfolding schemes [57], which is left as a future research direction.

V Convergence Analysis

In this section, we present the theoretical convergence results of our proposed MD-AirComp. We first introduce some assumptions needed for the proof. For simplicity, [𝐗^d]:,1subscriptdelimited-[]subscript^𝐗𝑑:1[\widehat{\bf X}_{d}]_{:,1} is denoted by 𝐱dsubscript𝐱𝑑{\bf x}_{d} in this and the following sections.

Assumption 1 (Smoothness).

Each loss function on the k𝑘k-th device, Fk​(⋅)subscript𝐹𝑘⋅F_{k}({\cdot}) is L¯¯𝐿\overline{L}-smooth, i.e., ∀𝐰,𝐰¯∈ℝWfor-all𝐰¯𝐰superscriptℝ𝑊\forall\mathbf{w},\overline{\mathbf{w}}\in\mathbb{R}^{W},

|Fk​(𝐰)−Fk​(𝐰¯)−⟨∇Fk​(𝐰¯),𝐰−𝐰¯⟩|≤L¯2​‖𝐰−𝐰¯‖2.subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰subscript𝐹𝑘¯𝐰∇subscript𝐹𝑘¯𝐰𝐰¯𝐰¯𝐿2superscriptnorm𝐰¯𝐰2\displaystyle\left|F_{k}(\mathbf{w})-F_{k}(\overline{\mathbf{w}})-\langle\nabla F_{k}(\overline{\mathbf{w}}),\mathbf{w}-\overline{\mathbf{w}}\rangle\right|\leq\frac{\overline{L}}{2}\|\mathbf{w}-\overline{\mathbf{w}}\|^{2}. (39)

This indicates the L¯¯𝐿\overline{L}-gradient Lipschitz condition, i.e., ‖∇Fk​(𝐰)−∇Fk​(𝐰¯)‖≤L¯​‖𝐰−𝐰¯‖norm∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰∇subscript𝐹𝑘¯𝐰¯𝐿norm𝐰¯𝐰\|\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w})-\nabla F_{k}(\overline{\mathbf{w}})\|\leq\overline{L}\|\mathbf{w}-\overline{\mathbf{w}}\|, where L¯¯𝐿\overline{L} is a constant.

Assumption 2 (Bounded Gradient).

Each loss function on the k𝑘k-th device Fk​(𝐰)subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰F_{k}(\mathbf{w}) has G𝐺G-bounded stochastic gradient on ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} norm, i.e., for all 𝛆𝛆{\bm{\varepsilon}}, we have ‖∇Fk​(𝐰,ξ)‖≤Gnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰𝜉𝐺\|\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w},\xi)\|\leq G.

Assumption 3 (Bounded Variance).

Each stochastic gradient on the k𝑘k-th device has a bounded local variance, i.e., for all 𝐰,k∈[K]𝐰𝑘delimited-[]𝐾\mathbf{w},k\in[K],we have 𝔼​[‖∇Fk​(𝐰,𝛆)−∇Fk​(𝐰)‖2]≤σl2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰𝛆∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑙2\mathbb{E}\left[\|\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w},{\bm{\varepsilon}})-\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w})\|^{2}\right]\leq\sigma_{l}^{2}, and the loss function on each device has a global variance bound, 1K​∑k=1K‖∇Fk​(𝐰)−∇f​(𝐰)‖2≤σg21𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰∇𝑓𝐰2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑔2\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\|\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w})-\nabla f(\mathbf{w})\|^{2}\leq\sigma_{g}^{2}.

Note that 𝜺𝜺{\bm{\varepsilon}} denotes a random local data sample. The bounded local variance represents the randomness of stochastic gradients, and the bounded global variance represents data heterogeneity among devices. Specifically, σg=0subscript𝜎𝑔0\sigma_{g}=0 corresponds to the i.i.d setting, in which the datasets of all the clients have the same distribution. Assumptions 1-3 are widely adopted in federated optimization problems [26, 23, 58, 59].

Assumption 4 (Biased Quantizer).

Consider a biased operator 𝒞:ℝQ→ℝQ:𝒞→superscriptℝ𝑄superscriptℝ𝑄\mathcal{C}:\mathbb{R}^{Q}\to\mathbb{R}^{Q}: ∀𝐳∈ℝQfor-all𝐳superscriptℝ𝑄\forall\mathbf{z}\in\mathbb{R}^{Q}, there exists a constant 0≤q≤10𝑞10\leq q\leq 1 such that

‖𝒞​(𝐳)−𝐳‖≤q​‖𝐳‖,∀𝐳∈ℝQ.formulae-sequencenorm𝒞𝐳𝐳𝑞norm𝐳for-all𝐳superscriptℝ𝑄\displaystyle\|\mathcal{C}(\mathbf{z})-\mathbf{z}\|\leq q\|\mathbf{z}\|,\forall\mathbf{z}\in\mathbb{R}^{Q}. (40)

Assumption 4 is a standard assumption for biased compressors, which was adopted to model scaled-sign and top-k𝑘k compressors in the literature. For such biased quantizer, there exists a constant γ𝛾\gamma such that, for global training round t∈[T]𝑡delimited-[]𝑇t\in[T], we have

(41)

which bounds the difference between the average of the quantized values and the quantized value of the averages [59].

Assumption 5 (AMP Estimation).

We assume that the number of non-zero elements in 𝐱dsubscript𝐱𝑑\mathbf{x}_{d}, i.e., ‖𝐱d‖0subscriptnormsubscript𝐱𝑑0\|{\bf x}_{d}\|_{0}, ∀d∈[D]for-all𝑑delimited-[]𝐷\forall d\in[D], is smaller than the length of the modulation codeword L𝐿L. This enables AMP algorithm to reconstruct 𝐱dsubscript𝐱𝑑\mathbf{x}_{d} with an estimation MSE of 𝔼​‖𝐱^d−𝐱d‖2=N​σn2𝔼superscriptnormsubscript^𝐱𝑑subscript𝐱𝑑2𝑁superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑛2\mathbb{E}\|\widehat{\mathbf{x}}_{d}-\mathbf{x}_{d}\|^{2}=N\sigma_{n}^{2}, ∀dfor-all𝑑\forall d [52]. In addition, we can assume the perfect estimation of the number of active devices Kasubscript𝐾𝑎K_{a}.

As described in (8), ‖𝐱d‖0≤Kasubscriptnormsubscript𝐱𝑑0subscript𝐾𝑎\|{\bf x}_{d}\|_{0}\leq K_{a}. In practice, the communication system can have prior knowledge about the maximum number of active devices Kasubscript𝐾𝑎K_{a} at each iteration, and can select an L𝐿L that satisfies Assumption 5. Note that this assumption simplifies the analysis, while we will describe how the estimation error affects the performance later.

In the following, we will show the convergence results444For simplicity, we only present the convergence guarantee for full participation of devices. Note that the theoretical analysis can be easily extended to partial participation according to [59]. of the proposed MD-AirComp-based FEEL scheme.

Remark 4.

It can be seen that the upper bound for mint∈[T]⁡𝔼​[‖∇f​(𝐰t)‖2]subscript𝑡delimited-[]𝑇𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm∇𝑓subscript𝐰𝑡2\min_{t\in[T]}\mathbb{E}[\|\nabla f(\mathbf{w}_{t})\|^{2}] contains three terms: 1) The first term, is due to the initialization error, i.e. f0−f∗subscript𝑓0subscript𝑓f_{0}-f_{*}. 2) The second term ΞΞ\Xi relates to the local stochastic variance σlsubscript𝜎𝑙\sigma_{l} and global variance σgsubscript𝜎𝑔\sigma_{g}. In the i.i.d setting, we have zero global variance, i.e., σg=0subscript𝜎𝑔0\sigma_{g}=0, and ΞΞ\Xi will be smaller and less dependent on the number of local training steps Tlsubscript𝑇𝑙T_{l}. Note that C1subscript𝐶1C_{1} and C0subscript𝐶0C_{0} are two constants related to the quantization error. If the quantization error increases, i.e., q𝑞q (0<q<10𝑞10<q<1) increases, C1subscript𝐶1C_{1} and C0subscript𝐶0C_{0} will increase as well. 3) Finally, the third term ΨΨ\Psi is due to the wireless communication errors, i.e., ‖𝐱^dt−𝐱dt‖2superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript^𝐱𝑑𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑑𝑡2\|\widehat{\bf x}_{d}^{t}\!-\!{\bf x}_{d}^{t}\|^{2}, ∀t,dfor-all𝑡𝑑\forall t,d. Note that if the wireless channel is noiseless, we have Ψ=0Ψ0\Psi=0. In practice, a lower detection MSE at the BS will reduce ΨΨ\Psi, resulting in a tighter convergence bound.

Corollary 1.

Suppose we choose the global learning rate η=Θ​(K)𝜂Θ𝐾\eta=\Theta(\sqrt{K}) and local learning rate ηl=Θ​(1Tl​T)subscript𝜂𝑙Θ1subscript𝑇𝑙𝑇\eta_{l}=\Theta(\frac{1}{T_{l}\sqrt{T}}), when T𝑇T is sufficiently large. With this choice of the learning rates, the convergence rate for MD-AirComp-based FEEL is independent of the communication errors and quantization effects, and satisfies

mint∈[T]⁡𝔼​[‖∇f​(𝐰t)‖2]=𝒪​(1T).subscript𝑡delimited-[]𝑇𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm∇𝑓subscript𝐰𝑡2𝒪1𝑇\displaystyle\min_{t\in[T]}\mathbb{E}\left[\|\nabla f(\mathbf{w}_{t})\|^{2}\right]=\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{T}}\right). (43)

VI Simulation Results

VI-A Parameter setting

In this section, we evaluate the performance of the proposed MD-AirComp scheme by considering FEEL for the image classification task on the commonly adopted CIFAR-10 dataset [4]. The CIFAR-10 dataset has a training set of 50,000 and a test set of 10,000 colour images of size 32 × 32 in 10 classes. We consider K=40𝐾40K=40 devices (unless otherwise specified) in the cell collaboratively training a neural network (the structure follows the ResNet [60]) with 269722 (i.e., W≈2.7×105𝑊2.7superscript105W\approx 2.7\times 10^{5}) parameters. We consider non-i.i.d. local training data across the devices as follows [15]: 1) Each one of the 40 devices is randomly assigned 250 samples from the dataset; 2) The remaining 40,000 samples are sorted by their labels and grouped into 40 shards of size 1000. Then, each device is assigned one shard555Note that the earth mover’s distance (EMD) for i.i.d. local datasets equals to zero [61]. In our simulation, we have EMD=1.44EMD1.44\text{EMD}=1.44, which represents highly non-i.i.d. local datasets [61].. Furthermore, we set the number of local training iterations to E=3𝐸3E=3, the mini-batch size to 20, the local learning rate to ηl=0.01subscript𝜂𝑙0.01\eta_{l}=0.01, and the global learning rate to η=1𝜂1\eta=1. The metric to evaluate the performance is the test accuracy of the model on the test dataset.

We adopt the K-means++ algorithm for VQ to learn the quantization codebook [62]. Since the distribution of the model updates changes from one training round to the next [25], we also update the VQ codebook to achieve better performance. We assume that the BS has available a small local dataset and performs local training as well. In each communication round, the BS obtains a local model update with error accumulation 𝐬′∈ℝWsuperscript𝐬′superscriptℝ𝑊{\bf s}^{\prime}\in\mathbb{R}^{W} as described in Section III-A. Then the BS uses its own local update 𝐬′superscript𝐬′{\bf s}^{\prime} to determine the VQ codebook. In particular, the D𝐷D data samples {[𝐬′](d−1)​Q+1:d​Q}d=1Dsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]superscript𝐬′:𝑑1𝑄1𝑑𝑄𝑑1𝐷\{\left[{\bf s}^{\prime}\right]_{(d-1)Q+1:dQ}\}_{d=1}^{D} are used by the VQ algorithm to obtain the quantization codebook 𝐔∈ℝQ×N𝐔superscriptℝ𝑄𝑁{\bf U}\in\mathbb{R}^{Q\times N}, where N=2J𝑁superscript2𝐽N=2^{J} is the number of clusters. Then, the BS broadcasts666Note that the number of real values in 𝐔𝐔{\bf U} is N​Q𝑁𝑄NQ. Considering N=256𝑁256N=256 and Q=20𝑄20Q=20, we can obtain N​QW≈1.9%𝑁𝑄𝑊percent1.9\frac{NQ}{W}\approx 1.9\%, which implies that the communication cost of broadcasting 𝐔𝐔\bf U is very small in comparison to broadcasting the updated model parameters. codebook 𝐔𝐔{\bf U} to the devices together with the global model. Note that we pad zeros at the end of 𝐬′superscript𝐬′{\bf s}^{\prime} to ensure that 𝐬′superscript𝐬′{\bf s}^{\prime} is divisible by Q𝑄Q. At the receiver, those padded elements will be deleted. Since W𝑊W is much larger than Q𝑄Q, the effects of padding can be negligible. Different quantization parameters J𝐽J and Q𝑄Q are tested in Fig. 3. We remark that the VQ quantizer is a biased quantizer as prescribed by Assumption 4.

As for the wireless transmission, we assume that 30% of the devices are active in each round. Since the BS does not exactly know Kasubscript𝐾𝑎K_{a}, we use 0.4×K0.4𝐾0.4\times K instead of the actual Kasubscript𝐾𝑎K_{a} in (23) as a prior information. We set SNR=20SNR20\text{SNR}=20 dB unless otherwise specified. For Algorithm 2, the damping parameter is set to τ=0.3𝜏0.3\tau=0.3, and the maximum iteration number to I0=50subscript𝐼050I_{0}=50. The elements of modulation codebook 𝐏∈ℂL×N𝐏superscriptℂ𝐿𝑁{\bf P}\in\mathbb{C}^{L\times N} obey i.i.d. complex Bernoulli distribution, which satisfies the restricted isometry property and is commonly adopted in CS [40]. In addition, as mentioned in Remark 2, to avoid extremely small SNR at the first receive antenna, we set ϵh=0.14subscriptitalic-ϵℎ0.14\epsilon_{h}=0.14 as the threshold of pre-equalization. We note that in practice, this threshold can be determined by the transmit power constraint.

For comparison, we consider the following schemes. IFed: IFed is the acronym for ideal federated learning, where the communication channels are assumed ideal and there is no quantization distortion. The IFed algorithm adopted for the simulations is FedAvg777Note that all the schemes are built upon FedAvg in our simulation for the sake of fairness, while FedAvg can be replaced by other optimization algorithms, e.g., adaptive federated optimizer (FedAdam) [58], for better convergence. [45]. PA (J𝐽J, Q𝑄Q): Here, PA is the acronym for perfect aggregation at the receiver, while the transmitter is the same as the proposed MD-AirComp scheme. The number of quantization bits and the VQ dimension are denoted by (J𝐽J, Q𝑄Q). MD-AirComp (J𝐽J, Q𝑄Q, L𝐿L): The proposed MD-AirComp scheme, where the number of quantization bits, the VQ dimension, and the length of modulation codewords are denoted by (J𝐽J, Q𝑄Q, L𝐿L). Different numbers of antennas M𝑀M at the BS are also tested in the simulations. OBDA: The state-of-the-art digital AirComp scheme with one-bit quantization introduced in [29]. Note that the main parameters of the OBDA scheme are adopted as released in [29]. However, we observed that learning rate has a significant impact on the convergence of OBDA, especially when dealing with non-i.i.d. local training data. To achieve a better test accuracy of OBDA, we carefully choose the cosine annealing scheduler [63] for learning rate adaptation, where the initial learning rate is 0.001, the minimal learning rate is 0.0001, and the cosine function follows a period of 1400. FSK-MV: FSK-MV is the acronym for frequency shift keying-based majority vote proposed in [30], which is the best performing FSK-based method in terms of communication overhead [30, 31]. Based on SignSGD, the learning parameters of FSK-MV are the same as OBDA. At the transmitters, each binary element of the model update vector is transmitted by sending a fixed power pilot signal on either of the two pre-allocated subcarrier frequencies. No pre-equalization needed at the transmitter. The receiver detects the signal power on the two subcarriers for majority voting.

VI-B Communication Overhead

Furthermore, we compare the communication overhead of different schemes. We consider an orthogonal frequency-division multiplexing (OFDM) system, where P𝑃P subcarriers are available. Due to the large number of devices, the communication overhead is dominated by the UL communications. We consider the UL communication overhead of one training round, i.e., Kasubscript𝐾𝑎K_{a} active devices quantize and transmit their model update (W𝑊W elements) to the BS. With one-bit quantization, the number of symbols transmitted by OBDA888Considering binary phase shift keying (BPSK) symbols as used in [29]. and FSK-MV is W𝑊W and 2​W2𝑊2W, respectively. It can be seen that FSK-MV does not require CSI at a scarifies of larger communication overhead. Furthermore, the proposed MD-AirComp transmits ⌈WQ⌉​L𝑊𝑄𝐿\lceil\frac{W}{Q}\rceil L symbols 999In our conference paper [1], real-value modulation codebook 𝐏∈ℝL×N𝐏superscriptℝ𝐿𝑁{\bf P}\in\mathbb{R}^{L\times N} was considered. In this case, if using I/Q channels, transmitting L𝐿L-real values only costs ⌈L/2⌉𝐿2\lceil L/2\rceil symbol. While, in this work, we extend the setting to a more general case, i.e., 𝐏∈ℂL×N𝐏superscriptℂ𝐿𝑁{\bf P}\in\mathbb{C}^{L\times N}.. Our simulation results in the following show that L𝐿L can be set smaller than Q𝑄Q, making the communication overhead of MD-AirComp smaller than that of the OBDA and FSK-MV schemes. In addition, for the above digital AirComp schemes, since all the devices share P𝑃P subcarriers, the number of time slots needed equals to the number of transmitted symbols divided by P𝑃P.

As for conventional digital communication, we consider the orthogonal frequency-division multiple access (OFDMA) and the quadrature amplitude modulation (QAM). For fair comparison, the same VQ at the transmitter is considered. After quantization, the index of each block (J𝐽J bits) is modulated to a QAM symbol. Hence, each device needs to transmit ⌈WQ⌉𝑊𝑄\lceil\frac{W}{Q}\rceil symbols. We assume each device is uniformly allocated with PK𝑃𝐾\frac{P}{K} subcarriers. Hence, the number of time slots needed is ⌈WQ⌉​KP𝑊𝑄𝐾𝑃\lceil\frac{W}{Q}\rceil\frac{K}{P}. We denote the conventional digital communication scheme as ‘VQ + OFDMA’, and we compare the number of time slots (i.e., transmission delay), of different schemes in Table I. As mentioned in Remark 1, Ka≪Kmuch-less-thansubscript𝐾𝑎𝐾K_{a}\ll K, while L𝐿L has values close to, or possibly smaller (due to devices collision) than, Kasubscript𝐾𝑎K_{a}, the transmission delay of MD-AirComp is obviously far smaller than the ‘VQ + OFDMA’ scheme. Numerical results in Table I verify the lower communication overhead of the proposed MD-AirComp scheme. Note that the best performance that “VQ + OFDMA” scheme can achieve is the PA benchmark, if considering perfect QAM demodulation.

VI-C Results of FEEL

In Fig. 3, we present how the test accuracy changes with the training rounds for IFed and PA (J,Q𝐽𝑄J,Q) for different J𝐽J and Q𝑄Q values. We observe that scalar quantization (i.e., Q=1𝑄1Q=1) with J=6𝐽6J=6 achieves nearly the same test accuracy as the IFed benchmark. In addition, the test accuracy under other VQ parameters nearly overlap. Note that when the VQ dimension Q𝑄Q increases, we need more quantization bits J𝐽J to convey the corresponding update with reasonable accuracy [55]. In the remaining simulations, we set J=6𝐽6J=6 and Q=20𝑄20Q=20 to test the performance of the proposed MD-AirComp scheme.

As shown in Fig. 4, the test accuracy of the proposed MD-AirComp scheme converges to the IFed benchmark. We see slower convergence and some performance loss in the final test accuracy of OBDA and FSK-MV compared with MD-AirComp, which is expected considering the one-bit quantization loss in these schemes. FSK-MV converges faster and improves the final accuracy compared with OBDA, while requiring a larger communication overhead. Furthermore, it can be seen that “MD-AirComp (6, 20, 15), M=1𝑀1M=1” performs worse than the PA (6, 20) due to the communication error under limited observation L𝐿L. Fortunately, by exploiting the multiple antennas at the BS, we can reduce the communication error without increasing the communication resources. For example, it is shown that “MD-AirComp (6, 20, 15), M=8𝑀8M=8” achieves nearly the same accuracy as that of the PA (6, 20). From Fig. 4, it can be seen that the MD-AirComp scheme is more communication efficient than ever the OBDA scheme, that is, to achieve the same test accuracy it requires the transmission of fewer symbols over the channel. In addition, although the MD-AirComp (6, 20, 20) achieves slightly better test accuracy as shown in Fig. 4, it is less communication efficient than “MD-AirComp (6, 20, 15), M=8𝑀8M=8”. This reveals that we can reduce the code-length L𝐿L, and hence, increase the bandwidth efficiency of MD-AirComp if more antennas are available at the receiver end.

VI-D Results of Wireless Transmission

In Fig. 5, we investigate the average sparsity ratio Ps≜∑d=1D‖𝐱d‖0N​D≜subscript𝑃𝑠superscriptsubscript𝑑1𝐷subscriptnormsubscript𝐱𝑑0𝑁𝐷P_{s}\triangleq\frac{\sum_{d=1}^{D}\|{\bf x}_{d}\|_{0}}{ND}, and collision probability of MD-AirComp (6, 20, 20) versus the global training rounds101010We observed that MD-AirComp (6, 20, 20) and MD-AirComp (6, 20, 15) have similar average sparsity ratio and collision probability during the training. For simplicity, we only present the related results of MD-AirComp (6, 20, 20).. We denote the probability of device collision occurred in D𝐷D blocks by Pc​1≜1−P​{d∈[D]:‖𝐱d‖0=Ka}≜subscript𝑃𝑐11𝑃conditional-set𝑑delimited-[]𝐷subscriptnormsubscript𝐱𝑑0subscript𝐾𝑎P_{c1}\triangleq 1-P\{d\in[D]:\|{\bf x}_{d}\|_{0}=K_{a}\}. In addition, the probability that more than two devices collide is denoted by Pc​2≜Pc​1−P​{d∈[D]:‖𝐱d‖0=Ka−1}≜subscript𝑃𝑐2subscript𝑃𝑐1𝑃conditional-set𝑑delimited-[]𝐷subscriptnormsubscript𝐱𝑑0subscript𝐾𝑎1P_{c2}\triangleq P_{c1}-P\{d\in[D]:\|{\bf x}_{d}\|_{0}=K_{a}-1\}. To enhance the clarity of the presentation, we employ logarithmic scaling on the x-axis. It can be seen that with fewer device collisions, the sparsity ratio increases along training rounds. The reason is that the variance of model updates gradually decrease as the training progresses[25]. Hence, with the same number of quantization levels, the values of different devices’ model updates become more distinguishable, resulting in a decrease in the collision probability.

For given number of observations L𝐿L and signal dimension N𝑁N, the reconstruction performance of CS algorithms gets worse if the sparsity ratio of the signal increases, i.e., as the signal becomes less sparse. The metric to evaluate the signal reconstruction performance is normalized MSE (NMSE), which is expressed as

NMSE=10​log10⁡(∑d=1D‖[𝐗d]:,1−[𝐗^d]:,1‖22∑d=1D∥𝐗d]:,1∥22).\displaystyle\text{NMSE}=10\log_{10}\left(\dfrac{\sum\nolimits_{d=1}^{D}\|[{\bf X}_{d}]_{:,1}\!\!-\!\![\widehat{\bf X}_{d}]_{:,1}\|_{2}^{2}}{\sum\nolimits_{d=1}^{D}\|{\bf X}_{d}]_{:,1}\|_{2}^{2}}\right). (44)

From Fig. 5, we can observe that the NMSE decreases due to the increase in the sparsity ratio. In addition, the NMSE of “MD-AirComp (6, 20, 15), M=8𝑀8M=8” is better than that of “MD-AirComp (6, 20, 1), M=1𝑀1M=1”, which verifies the performance improvement shown in Fig. 4. Furthermore, the NMSE of “MD-AirComp (6, 20, 20), M=4𝑀4M=4” is the best due to more observations. Although the NMSE of “MD-AirComp (6, 20, 15), M=8𝑀8M=8” is smaller than -10 dB when the training rounds is larger than 200, its test accuracy is as good as the PA scheme due to the error correction property of FL.

Fig. 6 illustrates the Kasubscript𝐾𝑎K_{a} estimation error. We consider the probability mass function (PMF) of the majority voting (MV) method and the mean estimation (ME) method for different MD-AirComp schemes. Note that the PMF results are calculated based on one realization of the scheme and on 1000 samples (training rounds). It is obvious that the MV method estimates Kasubscript𝐾𝑎K_{a} much better than the ME scheme. Furthermore, due to the worse NMSE performance, the Kasubscript𝐾𝑎K_{a} estimation error of “MD-AirComp (6, 20, 15), M=1𝑀1M=1” is much worse than that of “MD-AirComp (6, 20, 15), M=8𝑀8M=8”. Furthermore, Table II compares the performance of “MD-AirComp (6, 20, 20), M=4𝑀4M=4” scheme under various SNRs. It can be observed that the proposed MD-AirComp scheme still works well in low SNR, i.e., SNR=0SNR0\text{SNR}=0 dB or 555 dB, with a negligible loss in the test accuracy.

Fig. 7 investigates the performance of the proposed MD-AirComp in a larger cell with K=100𝐾100K=100 devices. This only changes the local training dataset setting, other parameters are the same unless otherwise specified. Specifically, each one of the 100 devices is randomly assigned 100 samples from the dataset, while the remaining 40,000 samples are sorted by their labels and grouped into 100 shards of size 400. We first evaluate the average number of non-zero elements, i.e., the average ‖𝐱d‖0subscriptnormsubscript𝐱𝑑0\|{\bf x}_{d}\|_{0}, denoted as ‖𝐱d‖0¯≜∑d=1D‖𝐱d‖0D≜¯subscriptnormsubscript𝐱𝑑0superscriptsubscript𝑑1𝐷subscriptnormsubscript𝐱𝑑0𝐷\overline{\|{\bf x}_{d}\|_{0}}\triangleq\frac{\sum_{d=1}^{D}\|{\bf x}_{d}\|_{0}}{D}. We consider different device activity ratios, i.e., 10%, 30%, 50%, and run the PA (6, 20) scheme to calculate the average ‖𝐱d‖0subscriptnormsubscript𝐱𝑑0\|{\bf x}_{d}\|_{0}. It can be seen that ‖𝐱d‖0¯¯subscriptnormsubscript𝐱𝑑0\overline{\|{\bf x}_{d}\|_{0}} can be much smaller than Kasubscript𝐾𝑎K_{a}, indicating a high collision rate among active devices (similar conclusion can be seen in Fig. 5). We reiterate that the collision helps to reduce the communication overhead of the proposed MD-AirComp scheme, and L𝐿L can be smaller than Kasubscript𝐾𝑎K_{a} due to the collisions. As can be verified in Fig. 7, considering Ka=30subscript𝐾𝑎30K_{a}=30, “MD-AirComp (6, 20, 25), M=4𝑀4M=4”, i.e., L=25<Ka𝐿25subscript𝐾𝑎L=25<K_{a}, approaches the PA(6, 20) benchmark very well.

Furthermore, in Fig. 8, we study effects of the various terms in the convergence analysis and Theorem 1 through simulations. According to Corollary 1, with the proper choice of the local and global learning rates, the convergence rate for MD-AirComp-based FEEL is 𝒪​(1T)𝒪1𝑇\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{T}}\right) and independent of the communication errors and quantization effects. This is confirmed in Fig. 8 as we see a roughly similar slope in convergence of IFed, PA, and MD-AirComp schemes. Please note that, IFed and PA are communication error-free, i.e., the third term ΨΨ\Psi in (42) is zero. IFed is also free of the quantization losses, i.e., q=0𝑞0q=0, indicating a smaller C1subscript𝐶1C_{1} and a smaller second term ΞΞ\Xi than that of PA. MD-AirComp has the third term that relate to both communication error σn2subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑛\sigma^{2}_{n} and quantization error C0subscript𝐶0C_{0}. From Fig. 8, the quantization effects seem to be more destructive. On the other hand, our proposed MD-AirComp technique seems to tackle the communication errors efficiently thereby achieving a performance very close to the PA benchmark.

VI-E Robustness to Imperfections

For simplicity, we focus on the received signal at the first antenna of the BS (pre-equalization applied at the device).

Here, we use 𝐲d∈ℂLsubscript𝐲𝑑superscriptℂ𝐿{\bf y}_{d}\in\mathbb{C}^{L} and 𝐳d∈ℂLsubscript𝐳𝑑superscriptℂ𝐿{\bf z}_{d}\in\mathbb{C}^{L} to denote the received signal and the noise of the d𝑑d-th, ∀d∈[D]for-all𝑑delimited-[]𝐷\forall d\in[D], block at the BS, respectively. In addition, denote hksubscriptℎ𝑘{h}_{k} and h^ksubscript^ℎ𝑘\widehat{h}_{k} as the actual channel and the estimated channel of the k𝑘k-th device, respectively. VI-E2 Imperfect Time Synchronization

To describe the effect of imperfect time synchronization, we follow the time-domain signal model of [15]. The received signal r​(t~)𝑟~𝑡r(\widetilde{t}) at the BS can be written as

r​(t~)=∑k∈𝒮a∑l=1L[𝐏𝐱kd]l​rect​(t~−τ~k−l​T~)+z​(t~),𝑟~𝑡subscript𝑘subscript𝒮𝑎superscriptsubscript𝑙1𝐿subscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐏𝐱𝑘𝑑𝑙rect~𝑡subscript~𝜏𝑘𝑙~𝑇𝑧~𝑡r(\widetilde{t})=\sum\limits_{k\in\mathcal{S}_{a}}\sum_{l=1}^{L}\left[{\bf P}{\bf x}_{k}^{d}\right]_{l}\text{rect}(\widetilde{t}-\widetilde{\tau}_{k}-l\widetilde{T})+z(\widetilde{t}), (46)

where rect​(t~)=12​[sgn​(t~+T~)−sgn​(t~)]rect~𝑡12delimited-[]sgn~𝑡~𝑇sgn~𝑡\text{rect}(\widetilde{t})=\frac{1}{2}[\text{sgn}(\widetilde{t}+\widetilde{T})-\text{sgn}(\widetilde{t})] is a rectangular pulse of duration T~~𝑇\widetilde{T}, sgn​(⋅)sgn⋅\text{sgn}(\cdot) denotes the sign function, τ~ksubscript~𝜏𝑘\widetilde{\tau}_{k} denotes the time offset of the k𝑘k-th device, and z​(t~)𝑧~𝑡z(\widetilde{t}) is the noise. For simplicity, perfect channel gain pre-equalization is considered in (46). Without loss of generality, we assume T~=1~𝑇1\widetilde{T}=1 and the time offset τ~ksubscript~𝜏𝑘\widetilde{\tau}_{k}, ∀kfor-all𝑘\forall k, is less than the symbol duration T~~𝑇\widetilde{T}. We fix a maximum time offset τ~~𝜏\widetilde{\tau}; then, we generate the time offset τ~ksubscript~𝜏𝑘\widetilde{\tau}_{k}, ∀kfor-all𝑘\forall k, uniformly in the set (0,τ~~𝜏\widetilde{\tau}). Similar to [15, 17, 18], by applying whitened matched filtering and sampling scheme, we get oversampled, but independent, samples from the overlapped signals (46). Then, the aligned-sample estimator (refer to Definition 3 of [15]) is applied in our simulation to estimate 𝐲^d≜∑k∈𝒮a𝐏𝐱kd^≜subscript^𝐲𝑑^subscript𝑘subscript𝒮𝑎superscriptsubscript𝐏𝐱𝑘𝑑\widehat{\bf y}_{d}\triangleq\widehat{\sum\limits_{k\in\mathcal{S}_{a}}{\bf P}{\bf x}_{k}^{d}}. Then, 𝐲^dsubscript^𝐲𝑑\widehat{\bf y}_{d} is used as input to conduct our proposed Algorithm 2.

In Fig. 9, we investigate the performance of the proposed “MD-AirComp (6, 20, 20), M=1𝑀1M=1” scheme under various imperfections, where “ϕ=π/6italic-ϕ𝜋6\phi=\pi/6”, “ϕ=π/10italic-ϕ𝜋10\phi=\pi/10”, “τ~=0.9~𝜏0.9\widetilde{\tau}=0.9”, and “τ~=0,ϕ=0formulae-sequence~𝜏0italic-ϕ0\widetilde{\tau}=0,\phi=0” are considered. From Fig. 9, it can be seen that the performance still converges to the same level of test accuracy at negligible loss of convergence speed. From Fig. 9, it is shown that both increasing the time offset and increasing the phase offset result in an SNR penalty, leading to degradation in NMSE performance of the proposed AMP-DA algorithm. Fortunately, the degraded estimation accuracy of AMP-DA algorithm is still acceptable for the FEEL task. In addition, as has been concluded from Fig. 5, it is also possible to increase L𝐿L and M𝑀M to further improve the NMSE performance of the AMP-DA algorithm. To sum up, our proposed MD-AirComp scheme is robust to imperfect channel estimation or imperfect time synchronization.

VII Conclusions

We have proposed a novel communication-efficient MD-AirComp scheme which can allow using over-the-air computation over legacy digital communication systems. The main idea of the proposed solution relies on the fact that, in AirComp, the receiver is only interested in the summation of the signals from multiple devices, but not the identities of the transmitting devices or their individual signals. The individual values to be summed are first quantized based on a common quantization codebook, then each quantized element is modulated into a transmit sequence selected from the common non-orthogonal modulation codebook. These transmit sequences from different devices overlap at the BS. Assuming that the number of transmitting devices is much less than the codebook size, the proposed sparsity promoting AMP-DA algorithm can efficiently compute the summation results by estimating which sequences have been transmitted, and by how many devices.

Furthermore, we applied the proposed technique for efficient model aggregation in FEEL, which is one of the most exciting parallel and distributed optimization applications. Here, the large-dimension model update is divided into blocks, and MD-AirComp is applied separately on each block. Our analysis proved a convergence rate of 𝒪​(1T)𝒪1𝑇\mathcal{O}(\frac{1}{\sqrt{T}}) for the proposed MD-AirComp-based FEEL scheme, where T𝑇T denotes the number of global training rounds. Simulation results verified that the proposed MD-AirComp scheme significantly outperforms the state-of-the-art schemes in test accuracy, and approaches the performance of ideal federated learning, despite using limited communication resources. Simulation results also verify the robustness of our proposed MD-AirComp scheme to imperfect channel estimation, imperfect time synchronization, and low SNR scenarios. There are various promising directions to explore, such as the development of adaptive quantization strategies (possibly layer-wise) for MD-AirComp, pursuing end-to-end optimization using deep learning, and investigating the applicability of MD-AirComp for privacy, among several other possibilities.

-B Proof of Theorem 1
